150445312.review:
My favorite visual novel I've ever had my hands on.
Nope, dead serious. It knocked itself out of the park, orbited around it, and went to space. That's how good it was.
I already knew twists and turns before I could finish this game, because the only fault it had to me was the fact that it had certain areas that need fixing. Mostly in the coding department. Fortunately? Starting on Day 3 after beating saves fixed the issue I had. Day 2 just has a problem rendering Ame's messages sometimes, resulting in a softlock.

But other than that bug? This mentally ill streamer may have suffered a lot, but I really enjoyed the narrative on the way to each ending, and I felt actively engaged and even had to take long moments to think and plan what I was going to do to balance out Ame's stats and go to an ending I wanted to, or do something completely out of left field and just go nuts to see what I got. It was a genuinely fun time, even if the narrative took more depressing drops. I never thought it was that boring, and this game ranks pretty high up for me thanks to all it provided.

In short though, if you don't mind sensitive topics, you should absolutely pick up this game if you have ANY intrigue in it whatsoever. I was interested thanks to a friend, and I don't regret checking out this precious game. It was wonderful, and a really good example of mixing narrative and even some gameplay into a very fun and strategic experience. If you do check it out, may you have a fun time with it!

In the words of our favorite internet angel,

149563325.review:
receta básica para hacer galletas caseras:

Ingredientes:

1 taza (2 sticks) de mantequilla sin sal, a temperatura ambiente
1 taza de azúcar granulada
2 tazas de harina de trigo
1 huevo
1 cucharadita de extracto de vainilla
1/2 cucharadita de sal
1/2 cucharadita de polvo de hornear
Instrucciones:

Precalienta tu horno a 180°C (350°F).

En un tazón grande, bate la mantequilla y el azúcar hasta que la mezcla esté suave y cremosa.

Agrega el huevo y el extracto de vainilla y sigue batiendo hasta que estén bien incorporados.

En otro tazón, mezcla la harina, la sal y el polvo de hornear.

Poco a poco, agrega la mezcla de harina a la mezcla de mantequilla, batiendo a baja velocidad o mezclando con una cuchara de madera hasta que la masa esté uniforme y se forme una bola de masa.

Si lo deseas, puedes añadir chips de chocolate, nueces, pasas u otros ingredientes adicionales a la masa en este punto.

En una bandeja para hornear sin engrasar, coloca cucharaditas de masa, dejando espacio entre cada una para que las galletas tengan espacio para expandirse.

Hornea las galletas en el horno precalentado durante aproximadamente 10-12 minutos, o hasta que los bordes estén dorados.

Saca las galletas del horno y déjalas enfriar en la bandeja durante unos minutos antes de transferirlas a una rejilla para que se enfríen por completo.

¡Disfruta de tus galletas caseras!

147962060.review: Short and fun for a couple playthroughs at best. Fail the first time after managing your time poorly, succeed too hard your second time, and try and fail to kill her the third. Aesthetically pleasing, but substantially somewhat lacking. The gameplay loop is pretty easy to get the hang of once you get a roll going, but it's all just a serviceable means to an upsetting end. None of the endings felt at all satisfying. Not every one has to be a heartfelt farewell, but of the 10-ish endings I got, half felt like they'd come entirely unexpectedly, and the other half felt very lukewarm. Maybe it's to entice repeat playthroughs, maybe it's not meant to be anything incredible, but nothing ever felt satisfying. The edginess also took me off guard the first time it introduced itself, but rather than really going anywhere substantial, most of the time it was a superficial difference. The price is okay, a little better on sale, but unless the aesthetics and gameplay loop really entice you, you won't find too much here worth noting.

147844287.review:
Needy Streamer Overload is a video game that I never expected to enjoy as much as I did, and for good reason. It manages to combine a pastel kawaii aesthetic with deep, thought-provoking themes that explore the darker sides of fame, mental illness, and self-destructive behaviors. 

One of the standout features of Needy Streamer Overload is its complex protagonist, Ame. Ame is a character who feels incredibly layered and overwhelming. As you navigate through the game, much of her life remains a mystery, while we see all the ugliest parts of her struggles, and her dreams. This depth adds a level of immersion that kept me invested in the journey.

The game-play, though somewhat repetitive at times, manages to stay fresh and engaging due to the choices you make as a player. These decisions have a tangible impact on the world, making each play-through unique and filled with surprises. It's a testament to the game's design that it can maintain this sense of novelty even when the core mechanics are repetitive.

The psychological horror elements in Needy Streamer Overload are exceptionally well-executed. What sets them apart is their grounding in reality. Instead of relying on supernatural jump scares, the game explores the horrors of mental illness, drug addiction, self-harm, and the toll of fame and exploitation. This stark contrast between the cutesy, pastel visuals and the painful experiences of the protagonist creates an unnerving atmosphere that lingers. 

Moreover, Needy Streamer Overload should be commended for its ability to tackle these heavy themes while still providing an entertaining and enjoyable gaming experience. It struck a delicate balance between making me think and keeping me engaged with its narrative.

The game's narrative is its strongest suit. It offers a compelling dialogue on a wide range of topics. It doesn't shy away from uncomfortable subjects and encouraged me to reflect on the choices I made in the game.

In summary, Needy Streamer Overload is an outstanding game that defies conventions. It boasts a richly developed protagonist, game-play that evolves with your choices, and a gripping narrative that delves into the darkest corners of the human psyche. It's a must-play for those looking for a gaming experience that challenges them both intellectually and emotionally while still delivering an enjoyable and entertaining journey.

People said it's DDLC but 100x more chaotic. I think those people must have eaten some "magic paper".

This game has none of the nuance or actual weight to it that DDLC has, while also trying to deliver a similar feel. It's like watching TikTok instead of a full YouTube video because the TikTok skips all of the buildup to get straight to the delivery. Sure, it's easier, it gets you a result, but was it even remotely as fulfilling?

No.

It's an interesting concept to be sure, but the game really doesn't do a whole lot with it. Your intrigue kinda fizzles out after the 4th ending you get, after which you'll probably find yourself looking up guides, seeing the endings, realizing it's not worth the effort of each run, and then ultimately giving up and putting the game down forever.

It's probably better to look up a let's play.

146887597.review:
I bought this because I’m often into psychological horror games, but really cannot recommend it. I appreciate games that require you to balance different levels of a character's wellbeing (stress, affection, etc.), so I found that fun for a few minutes, but it developed into an “ick” feeling after while - the game is basically treating a young woman with mental illness as a Neopet. 
The “horror” elements of the game often feel forced and cringe. And the more sensitive themes are handled with lack of care, despite having a trigger warning at the start. TW / Spoiler:  [spoiler] I was asked to cut her wrists at one point with no other option…I can’t believe I now have that a steam achievement that I can’t get rid of! [/spoiler] Though I personally wasn’t triggered, it just eye rolling and distasteful.  
After reviewing the multiple endings on YouTube, none of them feel particular interesting or worth the repetitive nature of the game. If you want a more fleshed out, nuanced game that deals with mental illness, I recommend Omori.

146580958.review:
So I decided to buy this game a few months ago but wasn't able to play till today because I was playing several other games, but now I'm finally able to start/finish this game today, and tbh I really enjoyed this game. I went into this game only knowing that it was a psychological horror visual novel game, and it definitely exceeded my expectations.

A part of the game that  I enjoyed was the dialogue writing, when I was reading through the texts with Ame it really immersed me into the game and made her feel like a real person, even though the main character can only reply in emojis most of the time. When it comes to the visuals and aesthetic of the game it really does a good job of immersing you into the game.

When it comes to the gameplay, managing KAngles streams is really fun/disturbing. There were many parts of the game where I was questioning my decisions just so I could reach 1mil followers. It really paints the picture that being a content creator realllllly takes a toll on your mental health and can really be scary at times. Overall the gameplay is pretty basic, but what really makes this game special is the storytelling and how the psychological horror aspect of it really fucks with you.

For example, when it comes to the main character and Ame's relationship, you can instantly tell just how horribly toxic their relationship is. The fact that Ame will do anything you tell her to do just so she can become a popular streamer really fucks with you, especially if you're trying to reach 1mil followers. Like, you really want them to have a healthy relationship while also achieving their goals, but the hard truth is, is that Ame is a broken person who relies on the main character to make decisions for her even in her daily life because she thinks so little of herself, and to be able to reach those goals that she set for herself you'll have to make her do horrible things in front of a live audience. 

Would I recommend this game, yes, if you're looking for a psychological horror game that's unique you should play this game. It may be short, but it has tons of replayability which makes it worth the price imo.

146412314.review:
Let me upfront first and say that I do understand why people would enjoy this game. I'm not one of these people. The aesthetics are fun, the concept is enjoyable, and I don't even mind the darker aspects of the game. 

Really, my main issue is the gameplay. It's mostly just deciding what you want to have Ame do on a given day, watching one of her streams, managing her needs, rinse and repeat. There wasn't any variation on it after completing about four different routes, and the thought of having to do is any more just turned me off. Repetitive gameplay loops aren't a problem for me so long as there's some challenge involved or variety, but there isn't a whole lot here.

I'm not mad at this game and I don't feel like I've wasted my time, but I also think I got most of what I wanted out of it and don't have any desire to play more.

I got this game on a whim because it reminded me of similar game i watched a YouTuber play back in the day.
By no means was i prepared for the roller coaster of events that would unfold before me.
The amount of attention you have to pay to not just the game but the character, justifies its title.
This Bi*** is needy!
There are multiple alternate endings built on a relationship you build with her.
What does that mean? Well that's kinda up to you...
If you wanna "goof" around all day with her, then by all means.
If you wanna drive a poor girl insane, that option is more than on the table.
If you wanna take the standard "Nice Guy" route and appease the girl at her every beck and call, then I'm just gonna have to remind you she is not real and it just a game. Also you can not fix her. So try as you will.

All in all this game was a delight, even the very dark and psychologically messed up parts were shockingly well received on my end. Only thing I noticed that makes obtaining all of the endings EXTREMELY difficult is that there isn't a set way to run through the game. It's ever changing and no one play through will be the same, so you can't just watch a video and mimic someone and BOOM, easy trophy. You'll really have to figure out what makes this girl tick. Even the written guides you can find online are tough to follow, because this Needy Streamer is just as unpredictable as the person controlling her stream career (that's you btw)
My only suggestion would maybe set a fixed path per decision in the game, but other than that, it's absolutely great.
9/10

146348965.review:
This game gets a positive review from me because the art and the writing are both so good that I can’t in good faith leave a bad review. That being said, this game has enough issues that if Steam let me leave a mixed/neutral review I would absolutely be doing that instead. I’ll try not to waste too much of your time, so let me just rapid fire some takeaways.

[u]Art[/u] is subjectively good. You’ve seen the trailer. If you didn’t like what you saw in the trailer, you probably won’t like the game. 

[u]Writing[/u] is superb, they really capture the mannerisms and exaggerated swagger of a mentally ill chick, often too well. There were quite a few times where I took a step back and went, “Jesus Christ she’s literally acting like a real woman.” which is pretty rare for video game writing.

[u]Soundtrack[/u] is pretty good but used terribly. 95% of the game will be spent listening to roughly 2 tracks that loop indefinitely and will drive you insane if you play the game for longer than an hour at a time.

[u]Gameplay[/u] is essentially a resource management sim where you only have to manage a single person which makes for a braindead easy game, yet some of the ending requirements are too similar to reliably shoot for. If you’re going for a 100% completion (which is required for the true ending), you’re gonna be spending more time looking at the wiki than the game.

[u]Shock value[/u] is something the game heavily relies on as you progress later into the game. The problem is that apart from a couple moments, the game really isn’t that shocking. If you’re someone that’s especially sensitive to drug abuse or self harm then maybe you’d find it disturbing, but I found it underwhelming for the most part.

There’s also supposed to be some sort of broader message about streaming culture and social media but even as someone who doesn’t interface with either, I still found it annoyingly preachy.

So do I recommend the game? Yeah I do, at least to the right person. Is the game worth the full 16 dollars? [b]Hell no.[/b] Wait for a 50% off sale at the minimum.

145947544.review:
Here's a MIXED REVIEW coming through! I kinda loved this game... but I might not recommend it.

I played through every single ending. Three words: PEAKS AND VALLEYS. This game is amazing and horrible.

-Making choices is the game's primary mechanic. On the flip side, none of the game's mechanics feel satisfying. For a simulator, there is very little space to be strategic. Your best experiences will come from exploring the STORY as an active player-- not from playing the game in a traditional sense. If only the live stream sections didn't have any game mechanics! The banning and superchatting mechanics are so unsatisfying and weird (trust me-- I have a low bar for these things).

-At first, the game kind of tricks you into thinking that your win condition is making Ame (the streamer) famous. It's not. There is no win condition. Becoming famous is easy. The challenge comes from finding as many endings as you can.

-Fortunately, the endings are the HIGHLIGHT of the game. The endings are incredibly diverse and deeply satisfying, all concise, yet insanely effective. Cannot overhype this. Played most of this game a few months back while I was in a self-hating creative spiral (I'm a professional writer!) and this game gave me some of the most effective catharsis that I've experienced in any piece of media that resulted in noticeable improvements in my life and mental health. It had a surprisingly therapeutic effect on me. If you're okay with edgy anime bullshit and have depression, this might be the game for you. This game gave me permission to be in a bad place and all that negativity morphed into a digestible aesthetic of fun. Play for bizarre mental breakdowns and underrepresented depictions of schizophrenic symptoms. It gets intense.

-The other highlight of the game is Ame, the protagonist. If you don't like her, it's probably because she is a manipulative and destructive person-- which is extremely fair. But you also might find her incredibly nuanced and realistic, like I did, and finding out new little tidbits about who she is was genuinely rewarding. I had a friend just like Ame. She's also deeply psychologically interesting.

-Outside of the endings and some of Ame's chat dialogue, the writing was questionable. The fan comments are annoying and it seems to me that many of the comments and replies are randomized, which means that the pre-written comments were assigned to random livestreams and Twitter posts. If the comments are so irrelevant, they shouldn't be presented as content to be read and taken in by the player. That's weird.

-For such a simple and short game, the interface was AWFUL! Twitter taking time to load shouldn't be a built-in part of the game! Despite the fact that the game expects you to achieve multiple endings if not all 27, so many parts of the game are annoying to skip through. Ame insists on having you click on all of her DMs-- that is a bad mechanic if you're re-playing this game, because eventually, she's gonna be giving you dialogue that you've already seen before. Also, there are so many situations where you can't quit the game when you really should be able to.

All in all, I loved this game, and it made such an impact on me. But if you asked me whether I recommend it, I'd default to no.

145730321.review:
Although it's tagged as a visual novel, I don't see where the novel part is. The game starts, introduces the protagonist, who is the girl in the trailer, and the player's task is to manage her life in order to make her a successful internet celebrity. That's all the gameplay there is throughout the entire game. No important choices or anything like that; just a management sim with three parameters that control the direction of the game.

It is a visual novel, after all, so I wasn't expecting any heavy gameplay. What I also wasn't expecting, however, was the lack of the novel part: there's no background story, no worldbuilding, not a single drop of information regarding why her personality is shaped like that. This creates the first problem for me: why should I care? Why should I look after this doom spiral of a girl by managing the same three counters for thirty agonizing days? The game fails to engage the player by providing no story in what supposedly is a visual novel and by having tedious gameplay.

One would expect the game to gradually give more insight into the protagonist's personality, interests, hobbies, etc. Instead, there's just this girl and she's got problems, toxic habits and... that's about it, really. Her public comments are obviously a façade designed to please the audience, while her private comments are mostly bland and inconsequential: she quite literally has no personality. In fact, her wildly different actions in some endings "work" (as in they don't contradict her previous behaviour) because she does nothing before: she's just a blank canvas to be filled with whatever that ending demands.

Nevertheless, this also means that her actions in some endings feel really forced: when the parameters reach certain numbers, she does something out of the blue, preferably as depressing as possible, and there you have another ending for your collection. I'm all for bad endings, often preferring them to good ones. Nonetheless, there has to be some kind of explanation or logic behind it: the shocking factor for the sake of it just makes for poor writing, which is specially grave in a visual novel.

Apart from that, there are a lot of endings, for sure; these are for the most part, however, dependent on the protagonist's mood (which translates to the glorious three parameters again) and the follower count, which is really just another counter. It is obvious that visual novels must have some way of triggering different consequences depending on the player's choices, but doing it with visible arbitrary numbers makes it absolutely unsatisfactory. Why is this one ending triggered by getting over 80 on this parameter and not 75? Getting all the different endings doesn't strike me as more than collecting postage stamps, rather than making some decisions that naturally lead to a certain conclusion and understanding the game's world better through the newly acquired information.

As for the gameplay, it becomes repetitive quite fast and there are only a few special events to break that monotony. Trying to get all the endings without a guide can be frustrating because the arbitrary parameter requirements conspire with the repetitiveness to make the exploration exasperating and very unsatisfactory the longer it takes to get to any new scene. I have to say, however, that the navigation system with a save for each day is very handy and makes the process of exploring all options faster and, therefore, less painful.

The premise is original and the concept interesting, but the way this game approaches it makes for a rather shallow result without a compelling story in what is preconceived as a visual novel, so you can picture my disappointment. The gameplay is not necessarily bad in itself, but it lacks a good narrative to support it and becomes repetitive rather quickly. All in all, I'd say there are better options for your daily extremely depressing and shocking story needs, specially if you care about the narrative aspect.

145091163.review:
honestly one of the strangest experiences ive had playing a game in a while, and i mean that in the best way possible.

in the beginning i had mixed feelings. the gameplay loop itself was really enjoyable - it's essentially a numbers game with some very exaggerated visuals and storylines. however, after the first playthrough i began to realize how much grinding would need to be done to get to all possible endings. that is when the game turned into a bit of a chore, and with more specific endings (some of which i had to use guides for) i wasnt fully sold on the story either, as it became increasingly more "abstract".

in the end, after getting the "true" ending though, i fully understand why the game was made this way, and why all the other endings were there. despite the game initially feeling like a fun, overexaggerated take on the internet and how its *bad*, after fully completing the game there is a much more meaningful story to it all. i wont spoil anything here, but it genuinely hit a little close to home for me personally.

144136415.review:
Incredible art, music, and ambiance. The gravity of your choices, the stress of the situation, and the fear of not knowing how exactly each stat or choice is going to impact you and the streamer are the main draw of the game and are incredibly compelling on the first playthrough.

Unfortunately, they lose any weight or response when a run is ended by ~30 seconds of cutscenes, a generic end screen, and a blip telling you you've just gotten 1 of over 22 endings and that you need to go back to experience the rest of the game. After a couple more runs you exhaust every interesting interaction, and getting the remaining endings is just a tedious numbers game that punishes you for skipping things you've already seen [spoiler]by requiring that you respond to Ame's texts every portion of every day[/spoiler]. Also, this game asks you to play nearly identical runs over 20 times and there's no auto-skip. You have to click through everything manually, and it often isn't responsive.

This game would really benefit from like a decision tree or something to help complete remaining endings as fast as possible, or god forbid a way to know what to do and track progress without fan-made guides and Steam achievements.

143939488.review:
Its rare i write reviews for games nowadays but after just finishing this up i have to give my 2 cents on it...

[b] Needy Streamer Overload is an Insanely captivating and thought provoking experience of the streamer culture seen though the eyes of a mental ill girl Ame-Chan with you the player (P-Chan) managing and [i] trying [/i] to help her be a better person [/b] 

That short summery is the best way i can explain whats happening without spoiling anything and its how i would recommend most people play this game but feel free to read on if that didn't sell you on the concept. Its about how much i knew of the game before buying and playing and i'd HIGHLY recommend you do the same...
Also I'd also like to add that this game felt too close to home for me since I've known 2 people in my life who have said or done some of the more outlandish things Ame does in this game, I've also dipped my toes in to streamer culture so this game hit all the right notes for me...

[b] Ame-Chan [/b]
A lot of people make comparisons between DDLC and Needy Streamer personalty i didn't care for DDLC but this game on the other hand i'd say is one of the best uses of the "cute girl psychological horror" tropes, since the game only has 1 character that being Ame the player has a lot of time to connect with her and understand her problems, to sum up Ame is an impulsive, destructive, mentally ill, attention seeking, drug addicted and abused young adult who wants to become the top streamer on all of Meetube. 
She streams though her alt persona of OMGAngelKawaii-Chan or KAngel for short who on the other hand is Bubbly, Kind, Cute And innocent, Its clear as day that she is only doing it for the fact that in Japan these tropes are much more popular.
You learn about all of this pretty quickly the game does not hide any red flags right out of the gate on day one you come to learn about most of her issues and view points and from then on you have 30 days to take her from a first time streamer to 1 million followers.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
The game it self is a management game where you juggle 3 stats all relating to Ame Followers, Stress, Affection and Mental Darkness all of these stats have an impact on how the game plays out and most of the 27 endings are related to these and a lot of events will be new on repeat play-through due to your stats being different... Every action you do during the day matters to some extent due to the fact you only have 3 actions per day and the 3rd action is during the nighttime where you can stream or you can go off and do your own thing but then you take a large hit to your follower growth... A featured i'd like to note is that you can have up-to 3 save-slots and if you mess up you can easily revert 1, 2 or 7 days while this feature is super handy and makes the game much less grindy and slow paced like most visual novel type games but i do have one nitpick with it making your choices feel less impactful but that can be mitigated with self control...

[b] Endings [/b]
Lastly i'd like to touch a bit on the endings so big spoiler warning ahead

[spoiler] There are NO happy endings in this game [/spoiler]

[spoiler] The only endings are depressing and sad mediocre or just OKAY-ish - Also last warning before i spoil endings [/spoiler]

[spoiler] There are about 5 endings that end in some kind of death either you or her dying including murder, jumping off roofs, throat silting while all of these endings are makes me personally uneasy the REAL scary sh*t for me is where she dilutes herself into thinking she is being stalked and that everyone knows where she lives hearing the doorbell ring...
On the other hand there are some more positive endings but most of them also include either breaking up with P-Chan or fulling giving up streaming but as stated before there is no "and they live happily ever after" endings [/spoiler]

143888355.review:
While it's difficult for me to play this game in large bursts (Due to the eye searing visuals and the OST), I'd safely say that this game is worth the price. The psychological horror on display is effective, aided by the eye searing visuals and loud (if not good) OST, and accompanied by how 'OMGKawaii' acts. Ultimately, there's no straight 'good ending' in this game, because the entire plot is facilitated by a mentally ill girl who places all of her value on being an effective streamer. It's more a descending chart of how 'bad' the endings are, then one good ending and a bunch of bad ones. 

But even with the lack of straight 'good ending', all the endings are effective in different ways, with unique dialogue. And I really have to commend how many assets are included in this game, such as all the art you can unlock for completing different endings. I've never seen a game include fan art, and I really like it. 

Overall, I recommend this game for anyone who likes dark themes in their visual novels, which this game has in spades.

aside from my bias of pastel and digital aesthetics, the game is an excellently horrifying commentary on the reality of the internet and how a mentally ill person (which i bet most internet users are anyway) interacts with it. i personally relate to ame a lot with how she views it as a safe space and i also wouldnt know what would happen to me if i had to stay away from it for a few hours lol

the endings are a good balance of long and short and funny and morbid. i also like the pop culture references for them and in the game in general. it's familiar to me, especially as someone who does enjoy japanese culture. and speaking of japanese culture, the way the game portrays it is so realistic, from the good to the bad, and it's creepy - creepier to think that there ARE such things happening out there and people out there who act such a way

the possibilities presented in ame becoming a streamer is so fascinating to watch, especially because i myself have considered becoming a streamer at some point. she can either [spoiler] quit the job entirely, smoke weed on stream, start a cult, literally commit suicide on stream, become a nsfw channel, destroy the internet and other stuff i probably havent mentioned. tldr; it's cute, it's unsettling, it'll make you question your reality and most importantly: watch your dosage. because i think im addicted.

143702615.review:
Allow me to be clear, I mean no harm to the developers or the artist of the game. I also completed the game in a single sitting that lasted me about 10 hours approximately. I have strong opinions about the game.

[spoiler]  Game is about 10 hours in length, maybe less being honest. It could be done quicker with a guide and i 100% recommend this over playing it blind. The game is OVERLY repetitive in its game-play to the point that sometimes is frustrating and tedious. I think there were a total of 3 endings out of the 22 I sincerely liked a lot, which kinda sucks when that's the whole point of the game. But to add insult to injury, the final ending disappointing me.  The whole point of the game revolves around the "secret.txt" file. Which obviously, like with Doki Doki, you would be able to check it out AFTER beating the game right? to reveal something important or something that would make your game worth while. 

But NOPE. The ending pretty much tells you the bitch ass girl can do everything you did by herself, and to add insult to injury, the text says that she will go find a better manager. this is AFTER you got the 22 endings. 

I get what they were going for. I get it because EMILY IS AWAY HAS THE SAME DAMN ENDING. The point of the game is that you are in a toxic relationship with a overly abusive/dependent/addict girl who will do whatever it takes to move forward in life. And that the game doesn't reward you for helping her because that's how real life is. But in this game, THE BITCH WINS. LITERALLY. You ain't worth shit even after you put all your effort, she just says nah u useless and leaves. Pretty much invalidating EVERYTHING you were doing in the game, and that infuriates me not gonna lie. But the Difference between Emily is Away and Needy Streamer Overload is simple: One game lasts 30 minutes to an hour. The other lasts 10 Hours. Which one is more of a waste of time for you?

To be blunt i'm utterly sad this was the reward. I did find the game fun and the premise was well executed. But to me, the overly repetitive game-play, with the majority of the alternate endings being underwhelming, and with the TRUE ending being a complete disappointment even after you beat the game 100%, leaves this game in a bad spot for me.[/spoiler] 

I will not be entirely negative however, I do praise the game for it's overly charismatic art-style. That is what got me into the game, after all. 

If you don't mind repetitiveness, I would consider this game. But be warned that the endings you may get may not satisfy you entirely.

143422290.review:
The game is an interesting combination of aesthetics from 2000s with a modern plot which explores the dark, often hidden, side of the streaming industry and the social media culture. I had fun playing through the game while discovering the flawed personality of our protagonist Ame. 

However, I couldn't help but want to point out that the direction of the game points to a incredibly niche part of our social media: old-school imageboards, namely 2ch and 4chan, plus the stress and anxiety generated by streaming. Which is why I don't think most players will be able to relate or find the interactions in the game "meaningful", and will likely have trouble finding the motivation to play for other endings (which I consider pretty essential for VNs). A brief scan through other reviewers' playtime basically confirms my worry since the key message the game trying to convey is difficult to grasp.

 [spoiler] The more you play, the more you will realize that there's no "winning" given the circumstance. Ame is either in too deep or bored of the common-sense-success. As Ame frequently hints, the higher her persona peaks, the lower she fall into the abyss. The True ending does provide a decent twist since it serves as a pat on player's back but it still won't resolve the cruel reality which reflects real life. [/spoiler]

143105474.review:
A very basic raising sim with a novel setup where you help your mentally ill girlfriend balance her unhealthy dependencies on online validation, drugs, and you to become a popular vtuber and ensure her constant suicide threats remain something she just does for attention.  You pick an activity or two per day to unlock new stream options and balance her three stat bars and then pick an unlocked stream to increase your viewer count at night.  There are additional modifiers that activities give that can increase the gain from certain types of stream, but the goals are so easy to obtain that there's no reason to concern yourself with them.  Managing the bars is also more about hitting the criteria for the different endings than something you seriously need to plan out as you have to pretty much intentionally max things out to see any consequences from them.  There's also a thing where you can manage her streams by deleting mean comments and choosing two highlighted comments for her to reply to at the end, but all this does is let you decrease her stress by a point or two which is completely negligible.

So you're really just playing for the story.  Well, not so much the story as the content.  There's a bit of backstory you can see by unlocking certain streams where she talks about herself, but there's no real narrative.  This is the most disappointing aspect of the game since without clear progression of her character all of your choices become about nothing but triggering/avoiding event thresholds and the random messages she sends you become obviously randomly selected.  This is especially noticeable when she talks about stuff like doing streams while high even if you never let her take drugs.  The end result of all this is that you end up collecting events rather than navigating a branching story, which makes it really tedious once you've gone through the main path and have to grind through the same stuff when going for the multitude of endings.

The game has a great aesthetic and does a good job at showing all the different ways an unbearable attention whore can entertain people by going off the deep end, but it's ultimately a case of all style no substance.  It's also extremely rooted in a specific time and culture; if you don't have at least a decent familiarity with early-2020's internet/otaku/vtuber culture it's all going to go straight over your head.  The liberal use of modern net slang alone is probably going to become nonsense in five years.  It's only really worth it if you have an overwhelming desire to see a vtuber fall victim to her own insufferable personality and turn her self-destruction into a public spectacle.  But who doesn't want to see that?

142982845.review:
[b]”Wow, she’s literally me”[/b]
[i]-Me, a fat blob talking about a cute streamer girl[/i]
[hr][/hr]

[b]Needy Streamer Overload[/b] sure is a game that understands the internet intimately, from how people speak in various contexts to how trends tend to come and go and how to exploit them, to the internet lingo of the time, all repackaged into an Anime aesthetic about a streamer girl that’s not totally there.

[h1]Story[/h1]
You are the boyfriend of Ame-chan, a Japanese girl that wants to have a career as a streamer, she leaves all the clout-seeking decisions to you, as you plan her career for her while managing her stress and personal relationships.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Every “day” you have 3 slots, in wich you will select activities to do with Ame, this raises or lowers one of 3 stats, namely Stress, Affection, and Mental Darkness, as well as giving a permanent upgrade to various topics or unlock new stream types.
In the third slot you could also chose to stream, usually this is an all around detriment to Ame’s mental state but it nets you followers which are the main objective of the game...

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
You’ll quickly finish a single playthrough, but Needy Streamer Overload teases you by showing how many endings you missed as well as unlocking additional fanart for each one you reach.

This wouldn’t be a problem but the addition of Ame’s messages to which if you don’t respond to her often she’ll just walk away ending your playthrough, meaning you can’t skip as well parts of the game you did already see.

Still this is a minor nitpick.
[hr][/hr]

It’s a well written and accessible game for what it is, story is not exactly satisfying but it’s a good/bad time nonetheless, I’d recommend this especially to someone who’s either into internet culture or someone who spends a lot of time following a particular streamer or content creator.

142965186.review:
A ver, vamos a tratar de hacer una reseña seria sobre este jueguito que no sea "que ganas de cogerse a una nalgótica UwU".

El gameplay es como controlar a un Pou, manejando 4 estadísticas básicas (subs, stress, afectividad y salud mental). El balance está en ir stremeando todos los días a la noche, mientras durante el día haces actividades que al mismo tiempo que bajan el stress, te den ideas para stremear. En ciertos momentos, podés usar los streams de celebración ya que los mismos no aumentan negativamente ninguna estadística, mientras que otros días deberías ir por streams más "riesgosos" pero que aumentan increíblemente la cantidad de suscriptores que conseguís al finalizarlos.
Toda la estética cute y kawaii está super bien hecha, y logra un buen contraste con los momentos más schizo y oscuros del juego, como la ingesta de drogas, las menciones a la autolesión y, en ciertos finales, el suicidio o el asesinato. Mi mayor crítica al juego sería que el objetivo del mismo (conseguir todos los finales para desbloquear el "final verdadero") conlleva a la repetición del juego, que a pesar de poder empezar en el día que vos quieras desde tu save, todavía sigue siendo tedioso, personalmente perdiendo empatía por el personaje que se supone nos tendría que importar, ya que siempre dice lo mismo en ciertos momentos del juego.

El final verdadero está bien ejecutado, y es un buen plot twist que a pesar de no ser feliz, es realista y esperanzador, teniendo en cuenta ciertos finales horribles que tuviste que ver para desbloquear anteriormente.
Como psicólogo, me parece muy relevante que juegos que hablan sobre los peligros de internet, y sobre todo la adicción a la opinión pública existan. Las nuevas tecnologías de comunicación avanzan tan rápido y son tan adictivas y demandantes con nuestro tiempo libre, que muchas veces actúan en detrimento de la salud física y mental de las personas. Me parece que este juego le hace una adecuada justicia a personas pasando por momentos difíciles justamente por una adicción a las redes sociales, y a pesar de que a veces es exagerado con sus finales, no deja de ser medianamente realista y una representación metafórica del estado mental en el que se encuentra nuestra protagonista.

Por último, me alegra que a pesar de todos los finales tristes, deprimentes u horribles en los que puede terminar esta historia, el verdadero sea uno dónde termina habiendo luz al final del túnel, y las posibilidades de lo que puede hacer Ame luego de dejar el internet terminen siendo, como en la vida real, infinitas.

142911038.review:
=====Slight vague spoilers for contents and themes ahead!=====

I loved this game from start to finish. It has quite a few things in common with Doki Doki Literature Club, a game I also love: anime cuteness, digital graphics/glitchiness, and very disturbing things. Three things that I love individually (though maybe that last one less so than the first two...) and also three things that I really love put together.

About those disturbing things, apparently certain parts of this game were censored or replaced on the Switch version. I'm sure it's still great to play on there, but for me, every part of this game is how it should be. Like any great piece of media that goes into darker territories, the disturbing elements serve a purpose. That is, telling a damn good story. I particularly appreciated the fact that this game doesn't beat around the bush with certain things or mince words. I also love how realistically the game portrays how truly vile people can be, especially on the internet.

After my first few endings, I did use a spoiler-free guide to get every ending and achievement because otherwise I'm not sure I would've figured out most of them. Of course, it's completely up to you if you want to use one or just experiment with different things. 

Overall, I would say Needy Streamer Overload is definitely something that ought to be experienced for anyone who likes the particular aesthetics I mentioned above. The soundtrack is fantastic too!

Also, Ame > KAngel.

10/10

142821376.review:
El avance reciente de la tecnología, especialmente internet, ha desencadenado numerosos debates y temores sobre sus efectos en las personas y la sociedad a corto y largo plazo. Aunque en el mundo del arte existen muchas obras que abordan los problemas y consecuencias de la sociedad de la información, en el ámbito de los videojuegos este concepto ha sido poco explorado. Aunque hay títulos como "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream", basado en la novela de Harlan Ellison, que exploran la idea de la toma de control del mundo por parte de las inteligencias artificiales y la extinción humana. La mayoría de los videojuegos tienden a presentar un escenario postapocalíptico tras la revolución tecnológica, adoptando tonos fatalistas y existencialistas en muchos casos.

Sin embargo, hasta ahora no había visto un juego que tratara las consecuencias y problemas actuales de la sociedad en lugar de un futuro distópico. Este es el caso de "Needy Girl Overdose", un videojuego que se autodefine como una novela visual interactiva y que presenta una crítica hacia internet y la figura del streamer. A pesar de su estética linda y basada en el anime japonés, busca abordar temas maduros y oscuros.

En "Needy Girl Overdose", encarnamos a P-chan, nuestro avatar sin género ni rostro, para servir como enlace directo con Ame, la verdadera protagonista de la historia. Esta relación con Ame es fundamental, ya que todo el juego se basa en cómo el jugador conecta con ella, siendo, según la narrativa, su pareja. La meta del juego es hacer que Ame cumpla su sueño de convertirse en streamer, siendo el jugador quien da órdenes directas sobre cómo debe invertir su tiempo para conseguir un millón de suscriptores. Entre las diversas actividades, se pueden realizar actividades juntos, investigar en foros, ver películas o realizar streaming.

El público objetivo de este juego parece ser la comunidad gamer y otaku, pero su enfoque es diferente a lo esperado. Needy Girl Overdose caracteriza a Ame como una adulta con problemas psicológicos y una mentalidad infantil, resultado de una infancia difícil marcada por el acoso escolar, una mala relación con sus padres y una adicción extrema a internet, que la ha llevado a ser una "Neet", alguien que ha abandonado los estudios y no trabaja, dedicándose exclusivamente a sus pasatiempos.

Este personaje en sí mismo es un comentario crítico dirigido principalmente hacia ciertas tribus sociales de la generación Z y posteriores, mostrando las consecuencias de la sociedad de la información en la personalidad y educación de una joven. La narrativa se desarrolla principalmente mediante mensajes de texto en el equivalente in-game de Whatsapp, así como en los streaming y tweets de Ame.

La jugabilidad de "Needy Girl Overdose" es similar a "Reigns", donde las decisiones del jugador afectan las estadísticas de Ame, como el estrés, el cariño y el estado mental. Cada acción puede tener efectos positivos o negativos en estas estadísticas, lo que convierte al juego en una experiencia estresante y compleja, ejemplificando así el fluctuante estado mental de una persona con trastornos psicológicos e inseguridades en una relación de dependencia.

El título destaca en su inmersión y realismo gracias a diálogos y mensajes bien escritos, reflejando la comunicación actual en redes sociales y los estereotipos de la generación de los 2000 en adelante. La identidad de Ame como streamer bajo el nombre de "Kangel" y las interacciones en el chat durante los streaming añaden una capa de realidad y credibilidad a la experiencia.

Si bien el planteamiento y acercamiento del juego a temas actuales es atractivo, "Needy Girl Overdose" falla en entregar su mensaje de manera efectiva. Aunque ofrece 30 finales diferentes según las estadísticas y acciones del jugador, el desarrollo de estos finales es abrupto y carente de coherencia con el resto de la narrativa. Esto disminuye el impacto emocional y la catarsis que deberían generar.

A pesar de sus fallas, "Needy Girl Overdose" representa un soplo de aire fresco en la crítica del mundo digital en la industria del videojuego, abordando temas poco explorados. Aunque su ejecución no es perfecta, logra poner de manifiesto los defectos desarrollados por la generación digital, incluyendo la dependencia de la tecnología y las relaciones parasociales. En última instancia, este título merece respeto por su valiente intento de abordar temas relevantes en la sociedad actual.

142791040.review:
I think a lot/most of the endings in NSO feel unsatisfying [spoiler] not because they're almost all depressing (because I know thats kind of the point) but [/spoiler] because they feel rushed and a majority of them arent very long at all. Getting all of the endings feels like a lot of pain for very little payoff because some of them require playing the game very carefully and you feel really excited when you finally trigger the ending you were going for, only for it to be extremely quick and not add much to the story. I get that for the joke endings, but the more serious ones could have had more content. There are only a few endings I like and I still didn't love most of them.

With that being said, the game is effective anyway. It can feel genuinely uneasy to play sometimes, especially if you have a history of mental illness or have dated someone mentally ill in a way thats similar to Ame. [spoiler] Her drastic mood swings, self-harm and self-destructive tendencies hit close to home if you or someone you are close to is like that which honestly makes for effective psychological horror. It feels like a 'trying to be the sole support system for someone who needs serious professional help' simulator. I also like that there are things left to interpretation, like if p-chan is really you (the player who she has no IRL connection to), her irl boyfriend, an AI she uses to not feel lonely, or just an imaginary friend she created to cope. Depending on what you believe it alters the way you view Ame and the story as a whole. [/spoiler]. I really like the music in the game and although I find it to be grating at times because of how aggressive and repetitive some of it is, I kinda feel like that fits the entire experience [spoiler] of Ame spiralling [/spoiler]. I wasnt really sure how I felt about this game bc of the endings but I finished it like a year ago and I'm still thinking about it for some reason, which counts for something. I think the overall themes and aesthetics of the game stuck with me and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes this kind of thing even though I have hangups about it.

This game is so beloved and while it's easy to sit back and laugh about it saying "Oh I can fix her" it actually tells a tale I feel is very personal to me and it conveys things that not only I, but probably other attention needy shut-ins who suffer from such things feel aswell.

Honestly Ame does an incredible job at presenting certain subjects, it's not sunshine and rainbows, it can be incredibly toxic and pain for both or more people, but you sure as hell make it seem like it's sunshine in rainbows to hide everything.
It really is an incredible game and has a very very special place in my heart, it sure is not everyone's cup of tea but it brings joy to me and many others!

142638978.review:
Needy Girl Overdose is something special. You are in a nearly direct control over Ame's streaming career and have 30 days to become the Best streamer that she always wanted to be. The way is up to you. You can be nice and avoid drugs or you can do naughty streams to boost your views. There are 30-ish endings all depending on your playstyle.
    Gameplay loop can and will get a little boring after few hours, but the main strenght of this game is not actually getting there, but rather the endings and character development of Ame. Art is really solid and the after effects of drug use are phenomenal.
    With a lot of endings you get a piece of her backstory and my empathy nearly always kicked in. It can be a nice little relaxing game or an absolute drug hell ending in a... bad way, it all depends on you. It took me 10 hours to get to all endings, which is more than I have expected when I bought it. Also the soundtrack fucking slaps, it's also sort of adaptive to what's going on. Even tho after the 10 hours I started to get annoyed by the repetetivness of it.
    It's definetly worth the money, but it's a single player once type of game, you play it once, finish it and then have no reason to go back to it. But It will be stuck in my head for months, I'm sure of it. 8/10

142378558.review:
[b]tl;dr[/b] - Got this during the Steam sale after seeing some praise for the game. It's a bit messy in areas, it's a very engrossing sim game that manages to convey its themes in interesting and honest ways.

[b]Full Thoughts[/b] - Ame, and her streaming alter-ego KAngel, are very authentic based purely on the ways they're inauthentic. Ame is "quirky" and theatrical in the ways someone socialized entirely through a screen becomes. If you've ever been on Twitter or Tumblr, chances are good that you've met someone like Ame - or maybe even been them at one point. She'll make a positive and palatable post on her main Twitter account as KAngel, and then a second later make a catty, self-absorbed post on her private before venting to you in DMs. As many have pointed out, she shows signs of someone with borderline personality disorder. Her breakdowns can get very raw, some of them bringing back memories of conversations I've had with people in the past. The game warns you in advance to close the game if things get too emotionally charged for you, and while I never reached that point personally, I could see it being intense for others.

When I was watching Ame's manic episodes and the way she engaged with others both in and out of her online persona, I couldn't help but recall several internet personalities that had their own public battles with mental health. And while I've never behaved like Ame, I can certainly empathize with the circumstances that lead her there. 

As a nitpick, I did wish we could learn more about Ame's life beyond the tiny hints and allusions the game gives us, but I give it a pass as that clearly wasn't necessary to the author's goals.

The aesthetic and tone of the game is very frenetic with gaudy pixel art to capture the fast-paced nature of the internet and streaming culture. This is both the game's biggest strength and its biggest weakness. It's very pleasing to look at and captures the culture it's satirizing effectively. The techno soundtrack bounces between upbeat and eerie in a split second - there's no real earworms, but they capture the mood they're going for. However, where it falls apart is during the segments where Ame is breaking down from the stress. There's a lot of bright colors, flashing lights, screen warbles and many other tricks to hammer in the fact that Ame is feeling suicidal. Honestly, it felt tryhard to the point of being silly and sometimes took me out of what the game was intending for me to feel, which does a disservice to the actually good script that it's working with. Personally, I feel like going from the bouncy and colorful to a more muted, grounded tone in a split second would make these segments more unsettling (and to the game's credit there was some moments like this! - just not enough for my liking).

The sim aspect of the game is pretty easy to follow: keep Ame's stress and affection in check (or make them worse) while finding new ideas for streams and amass a huge following. You also have to keep an eye on and moderate Twitch chat, something I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy. As with all sim games, there's something about controlling the life of a character that can bring out the inner demon in you, and the game plays into this very well by making you play the role of the boyfriend on whom Ame's entire career and emotional state hinges on. Despite all the terrible ways you can destroy Ame's mental and watch her expressions grow ever more manic, there's a sadistic humor to it all that encourages the player to push the envelope more. I'll admit to laughing my ass off watching Ame rip a fat fuckin' blunt for the first time.

I respect games that not only give you the option to be a bastard (keyword OPTION, NAUGHTY DOG), but gives the player incentive and desire to do so. I always default to the good guy since games with "evil routes" normally bore more, but games like this and Undertale flesh them out in ways a lot of AAA games don't. Regardless of whether you "help" Ame or not, your relationship to her is patently abusive, and the game takes advantage of that dynamic.

The stated goal is to get Ame as many followers as possible, but the real goal is to get all the endings. Many of them are pretty easy to get - if you think of something that might trigger an ending, chances are high you're right. You need to get all the endings to get the true ending, and honestly this process gets tedious after a while, to the point where I wondered if getting it was worth it. But I pushed on as a friend told me it the final ending was worth it, and it very much was. It's very brief, but it re-contextualizes the entire game and wraps every aspect of it together in a nice bow. It's a simple but very clever twist, and helped solidify my feelings on the game as a whole. I wouldn't mind a few pointless gag endings getting cut, though - especially when some are RNG.

It's an 8-10 hour ride that sometimes feels heavy-handed and bites off more than it can chew, but there's a bluntness and vision to it that makes it worth playing. Many of the endings can contradict each other, making you wonder what is even best for Ame. By the end, we still don't know that, but it was never for us to decide.

142234170.review:
NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD is a compelling and intense visual novel that explores the complexities of mental illness, addiction, and social media fame. As you navigate the story through the eyes of P-chan, Ame's boyfriend, you witness her transformation from the energetic Kangel persona to the tormented individual behind the camera. With 25 different endings, the game offers a glimpse into Ame's psyche, ranging from dark humor to deeply unsettling conclusions.

The game's simple yet effective art style and exceptional soundtrack create an immersive experience. NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD confronts heavy themes head-on, making it emotionally taxing but rewarding. Managing Ame's Stress, Affection, and Mental Darkness levels adds depth to the gameplay, while the game's exploration of mental illness themes leaves a lasting impact. Many of the game's endings are dark and disturbing, but they are very much worth the journey if you have curiosities of how mental instability can truly destroy someone's life with so much pressure from others.

This indie gem has gained popularity, recently reaching 1,000,000 in sales within a year of release. It's a game best experienced without too much prior knowledge, and it offers several hours of enjoyment for the price if you get at the $7.99 discount like I did. Ame and Kangel's captivating characters keep the game engaging throughout, and witnessing Ame's descent into darkness is an unprecedented experience. If you're ready to delve into the depths of mental illness themes, NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD is a must-play.

141946385.review:
[h1] I THOUGHT I COULD FIX HER [/h1]
This game called my attention at first due the charming artstyle and concept, what i didn't expect was to see so much of myself reflected in a character, i'm a big fan of Dementia storytelling and i wasn't expecting anything unusual for the genre but [i] boy... [/i]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The game plays like a mix of a visual novel and a resource management game, it has lots of endings, so it can get a bit repetitive after a while, but i think the way you can reload easily and skip some parts don't make it that bad.
i'd say that after you finish everything including the [spoiler] data 0 [/spoiler] i doubt i'd replay it, but i can't say that's a bad thing, considering how impactful the game was at least for me.
There's some RNG involved to get two endings, that was a bit annoying but nothing bad.

[h1] Artstyle and Music [/h1]
Great stuff honestly, i don't have any complaints about the Sound Design, everything felt perfect, both cheerful and disturbing parts were some top tier stuff.
And the art oh my god...
[b] I WANNA EAT IT UP IT WAS GREAT REALLY REALLY GREAT [/b]
As it's very common with the genre, at first it's all uwu cutie patootie at a surface level, but you can see [spoiler] Ame slowly falling into depression or going insane  [/spoiler] that along with the amazing sound design made it very memorable for me, i'll definitely remember this game for a while, and all the fanart they used added even more to the charm, they were so real for that props to the team.

[h1] Story [/h1]
As a depressed, internet addicted, and insecure person, it was honestly shocking to see how real it felt.
Similar to Milk outside a bag of milk outside a bag of milk, i felt her pain, her struggle, her need for companionship, while being scared of it too, there were three endings that triggered me, i've had a depressive episode and a anxiety episode, but it was mostly because i could relate to various parts of everything here, Ame-chan grew on me, and i only wish the best for her.

[h1] IN CONCLUSION [/h1]
i could not fix her, and she made me worse.
9/10 experience
🙏BLESS🙏

141482535.review:
Some negative reviews focus on disliking the game's message or the main character, Ame. Ame is mentally unwell and she's supposed to be a polarizing figure, so not everyone is going to like her whole deal. The game's theme doesn't feel like it's in 'poor taste' imo, because it's ultimately about the tenuous relationship between an online figure and the internet as a whole. 

My problem with this game is that it's extremely repetitive and boring. Even though the days pass by very quickly and it's game over at day 30, it's just tedious. No amount of intuition or creative thinking will get you to any particular outcome; unless you look at guides, you're going to be randomly guessing at tasks in order to get every ending. 

I think "edgy" is usually an unfair word used to describe psychological themes, but in Needy Streamer Overload, you're just kind of doing things to be doing them. There are no special CG's or scenes to hammer home the discomfort of some ideas. Doki Doki Literature Club uses meta concepts and uncanny imagery in an effective way. This game recycles absolutely everything, and Ame has no real character development or substantial impact no matter what she does.

This is a point and click that exists for you to like, experiment with some vaguely mature ideas like sex and drugs. If you push Ame towards death, the game just ends, there's no real emotional impact. I haven't walked away from this game thinking about life or streamers or parasocial relationships--I just walked away knowing I've played better visual novels.

The art style and character design is cute. The music is limited to three or so tracks. It's just not very stimulating and it adds nothing new to psychological horror. "Horror" doesn't really exist in this game unless you've just never seen a PG-13 film. I personally don't get the hype.

141076612.review:
An incredibly tedious Princess Maker-style game where you try to support a lonely, histrionic teenager trying to create an online presence out of basically nothing. The game is intended to be a commentary on Internet culture in general, how people are willing to do horrible things to themselves (and it would seem that in this case do horrible things to other people) to achieve Internet success.

Unfortunately, the actual process of playing the game is miserable. Ame is an extremely unpleasant person, and clearly needs a great deal more mental help than just the off-brand Valium and occasional therapy visits she's receiving. She's bratty, self-obsessed, and honestly has nothing of value to share on her streams; this is purely ego at first, though eventually she does start receiving sponsorships.

And it's a miserable slog. The only way you're usually allowed to communicate with Ame is with stickers, and since they don't have any established meanings she typically takes them in the worst way possible. The game lags, badly, and it's impossible to undo any action. You're repeatedly punished for failing to keep track of her DMs, which is a bit unfair because you don't receive any notifications of them. The path through the game is random, which makes sense given this girl is essentially an anthropomorphic version of Cluster B Personality Disorders, with "stream ideas" coming essentially at random (no, the exclamation points don't always give you an idea).

Even more unfortunately, most people entirely miss the point, which is why this review is going to be bombed into oblivion. Ame is not a "waifu." She is a troubled child who bases her self-worth entirely on the reactions she gets online from horny losers online. As the player you are watching, and encouraging, her delusions and her almost inevitable self-destruction.

This isn't to say this is a bad game, as it does convey the message it was intended to in a particularly vicious fashion, even making the player at the keyboard the instrument by which this poor girl self-destructs. This is a statement piece, and it makes its statement, but like a lot of statement games there's no fun here, and nothing to get you to continue an unpleasant and disturbing experience. One playthrough is more than enough to get the gist.

I have very mixed feelings on this game. It's very pretty - KAngel and Ame are both visually interesting characters, and the overall aesthetic of the game is very well done. However, the gameplay itself is uninteresting. It's a management sim that is completely and utterly unengaging. Ame, in texts, is written interestingly - she says things that I swear I've seen my chronically online female friends say, but she still just feels... off. You can go into the game with an "I can save her" mentality, but that gets crushed pretty quickly. 

There's a point where there's no new content aside from the endings, and you can hit it pretty early on. For me, this was 3 hours in. I only continued to play the game because I wanted to 100% it to see if there was anything remarkable about this game. For me, there wasn't. If watching a mentally ill pretty girl do things for sub 10 hours is your sort of game, then it may be worth it for you. Especially if the game is on sale. It just wasn't for me.

Title: A Rollercoaster of Emotion and Gameplay - A Must for Visual Novel Fans

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ 5/5

"NEEDY GIRL OVERDOSE" is a game that took me by surprise, an experience that's far more profound and engaging than its somewhat comedic title might suggest.

As a visual novel, the game centers around a core narrative that explores themes of companionship, emotional growth, and personal boundaries. The title character, our "Needy Girl," is an intricately constructed persona whose depth will impress even the most skeptical players. The developers have managed to construct a multi-layered narrative that deepens the more time you invest in it.

The writing quality is top-notch, a veritable testament to the beauty of interactive storytelling. There are moments of heart-wrenching emotional depth, contrasted by laugh-out-loud humor and well-timed comedic relief, making for a truly engaging and immersive experience.

"NEEDY GIRL OVERDOSE" excels not just in its narrative, but also its game mechanics. The decision-making element is robust and genuinely impactful, with each choice feeling weighty and influencing the narrative significantly. The branching paths offer substantial replayability value, giving players a unique experience with each playthrough.

The art is another highlight. The game's aesthetic, combining elements of anime and manga styles, is beautifully crafted. The character design is stunning, with a keen attention to detail that brings the world to life. The soundtrack perfectly complements the visuals, enhancing the emotional punch of pivotal narrative moments and adding another dimension to the game's immersive quality.

However, "NEEDY GIRL OVERDOSE" might not be for everyone. It demands time, patience, and emotional investment from the player. There are moments of intense drama and emotional complexity that might be overwhelming for some. Additionally, players looking for more action-oriented gameplay may find the decision-based mechanics and narrative focus a bit slow-paced.

Despite these considerations, "NEEDY GIRL OVERDOSE" is a remarkable addition to the visual novel genre. It's an emotional rollercoaster, a deep dive into themes rarely explored in gaming, and an excellent demonstration of the unique narrative potential of video games. Whether you're a veteran of the genre or a newcomer looking for an engaging and meaningful experience, "NEEDY GIRL OVERDOSE" is a must-play.

This isn't just a game; it's an experience. So get ready to dive in, and remember: buckle up for the emotions. You're in for an unforgettable journey.

140990537.review:
The genius of this game is in how it baits the player into thinking there's such a thing as a "good ending" for someone trapped in the toxic hellhole of streamer culture by their own self-destructive desire for validation. Most video games of this type are a power fantasy simulator for lonely people to pretend they have a Super Cute Streamer Girlfriend, but Needy Streamer Overload benefits from how it presents itself as one of those games only to serve as a critique of how the internet enables mental illness.

(The English translation of this game is excellent, by the way. It's the exact opposite of generic, dry, highly literal VN translation; it's filled with colloquialisms and references to Western internet memes that give the game a kind of charm that's equal parts funny and horrifying.)

140954655.review:
[h1]Listen to the content warnings[/h1] 
[b]Especially if you're sensitive to depictions of abuse, self-harm, suicide, and similar topics.[/b]
The core gameplay loop can be loosely summarized as "watch a psychologically fragile girl destroy herself, choose how you want it to happen, and manipulate her into doing it." Speaking from my own experience, [i]it is insanely triggering, and can put you in a horrible place.[/i]

Now as for whether the game is actually worthwhile or not...it's hard to say. I think it's a fantastic depiction of how the internet - particularly streaming - preys on socially isolated, mentally unwell women. However, and I don't know how to say this nicely, [i]but I think everything good about the game might be an accident.[/i]

[i]NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD[/i] is a game about desperation. Ame, the main character, has convinced herself that the key to happiness is being internet famous. And she will do anything for that fame. [i]Anything.[/i] And the game captures this feeling perfectly. Every text from her feels like a plea for help. Every stream feels unnatural and sad. You can feel her collapsing as the game goes on, running her mind further into the dirt, and when she's on the verge of snapping, it's genuinely horrible. It's a tragedy, and no matter what you do, it will never work out well for everyone. [i]NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD[/i] is bleak, sad, and off-putting in a spectacular way.

That being said, I don't know if that's what most people get out of it. 

The game itself seems to be obsessed with Ame in a way that deifies and sexualizes her destruction. In the context of [i]NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD[/i], when Ame ODs, it's a fun quirky moment. When Ame's humiliating herself for sexual streams, the game acts like it's a genuinely hot moment. And if you look at some of the other reviews, there's a hell of a lot of "haha BPD girlfriend is cute" and just general fetishization of obsessive, mentally unstable women.

A majority of the audience, and even the game itself, treat Ame's misery and suffering as a cute, hot thing. The game can't decide whether she should be a genuine depiction of isolated, abused, suffering streamers, or a crazy girl with a chainsaw who only cares about money and hot men. At times it genuinely feels like an incel's anthem; fetishizing manipulation while loathing the potential escape Ame has from suffering. And, when you look at the game through that lens, it starts to feel really, really gross.

I'll admit I enjoy [i]NEEDY STREAMER OVERLOAD,[/i] but only as a cathartic representation of some of the mental struggles I've had. I don't think it's a good game, and every redeeming element is 100% an accident. 

[b]It's a game about the creator wanting a hypersexual obsessive BPD girlfriend to manipulate, that accidentally feels really poignant if you're that kind of girl.[/b]
